name: Kepler-139
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-139 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-139 is a star with 1.694 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.3 times its radius. It is located 1289.78 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-139 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-139 b

Kepler-139 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 15.77 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-139.

The mass of Kepler-139 b is 12.77 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-139 b is 2.94 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-139 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-139 c

Kepler-139 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.59 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 157.07 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-139.

The mass of Kepler-139 c is 17.95 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-139 c is 3.38 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-139 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-139, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
